conclusion: Determine how much the point source S should be moved vertically upward so that the light emitted is just not visible above the surface of the liquid.
The critical angle is the angle of incidence in the denser medium (liquid) at which light is refracted at 90 degrees (along the boundary).
Calculate the critical angle using sin(theta_c) = 1/n where n = sqrt(2), resulting in theta_c = 45 degrees.
The light source S is directly below the center O of the circular board at a depth H = sqrt(3)r.
Let h be the distance the source S is moved upward so that the light is just not visible.
The geometry forms a right triangle with hypotenuse H - h, opposite side r, and angle of incidence theta_c = 45 degrees.
Using the definition of sine in the right triangle, sin(theta_c) = r/(H - h).
Substitute known values into the equation sin(45 degrees) = r/(sqrt(3)r - h).
Solve for h by cross-multiplying and simplifying the equation sqrt(2)/2 (sqrt(3)r - h) = r.
Further simplify to find h = r(sqrt(3) - sqrt(2)).
The distance the point source S should be moved vertically upward is h = r(sqrt(3) - sqrt(2)).
